card.name: 9) Protect users' privacy
card.desc:
Evaluate what data and information the service will be providing or storing. Address the security level, legal responsibilities, privacy issues and risks associated with the service (consulting experts where appropriate).

**Why its important**

Government services often hold confidential and sensitive information about users. Government has a legal duty to protect this information. And failing to do so would undermine public trust in government services. 

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to see:

- that youve identified security and privacy threats to the service
- that you have a robust, proportionate plan and budget for managing security during the life of the service (for example, responding to threats and applying security patches to software)
- that youve identified fraud vectors and put controls in place
- that youre [collecting users personal information](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1STnlJYyHUGNpMxJuPCGG5J9FZX4PmxkyHxs3poDNtYw/edit) in a way thats secure
- that if the service needs an authentication solution, youve [picked one -
 that balances the risks in a proportionate way](link to new guidance)
- that youre working with business and information risk teams (for example, senior information risk owner (SIRO) information asset owner (IAO) and data guardians) to make sure you meet security regulations without putting delivery at risk
- that youve carried out appropriate [vulnerability and penetration testing](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/vulnerability-and-penetration-testing)

list.name: NEW Standard - C) Using the right tools and technology

card.name: 17) Test the technology
card.desc:
Test the technology youre working with regularly. 

**Why its important**

Testing is the only way to be confident that your service can cope with the demands likely to be placed on it, and that it works on a wide range of devices.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know that you:

- have an [effective deployment environment](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/making-software/deployment.html)
- can create new environments quickly and easily
- know the data that exists in your pre-production environments
are carrying out [quality assurance testing](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/quality-assurance-testing-your-service-regularly) regularly
- are testing your service in an environment thats as similar to live as possible
- have tested the front end with the [required combination of browsers and devices](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/designing-for-different-browsers-and-devices#test-for-compatibility)

list.name: NEW Standard - C) Using the right tools and technology

card.name: 16) Make new source code open
card.desc:
Make all new source code open and reusable, and publish it under appropriate licences. Or if this isnt possible, provide a convincing explanation of why this cant be done for specific subsets of the source code.

**Why its important**

Public services are built with public money. So unless theres a good reason not to, the code theyre based should be made available for people outside government to reuse and build on.

Open source code can be reused by developers working in government, avoiding duplication of work and reducing costs for government as a whole. And publishing source code under an open licence means that youre less likely to get locked in to working with a single supplier.  

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want:

- to see that youve written code in the open from the start, and published it in a repository on the internet - minus any sensitive information, like secret keys and credentials
- confirmation that government owns the intellectual property in the code, and that youre publishing it under an open licence

There are a few cases when [you must not publish code in the open](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/open-source-guidance/when-code-should-be-open-or-closed). For example, code that relates to a sensitive government policy that hasnt been announced yet.

**Further reading**

- [Making source code open and reusable](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/making-source-code-open-and-reusable)
- [The benefits of coding in the open](https://gds.blog.gov.uk/2017/09/04/the-benefits-of-coding-in-the-open)

list.name: NEW Standard - C) Using the right tools and technology

card.name: 15) Use and contribute to common standards, components and platforms
card.desc:
Where possible, build on common standards, components and patterns from inside and outside government. If you develop your own patterns or components, share them publicly so others can use them.

**Why its important**

Using common components and patterns means you dont have to solve problems that have already been solved. By using a component or pattern thats already been extensively tested, you can provide users with a good experience in a cost effective way.

If you develop your own components or patterns, its important to share them so that others can benefit from your work.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to see that youre:

- using and contributing to [open standards](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/working-with-open-standards) where possible
- using [standard government technology components](https://www.gov.uk/government/policies/government-as-a-platform) where possible, for example GOV.UK Verify for identity assurance
- making it as easy as possible to reconfigure your service and for others to build on it, for example by using and creating [application programming interfaces (APIs)](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/choosing-technology-an-introduction) and [registers](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/registers) where possible
- [publishing all data as open data](http://guidance.data.gov.uk/publishing_on_data_gov_uk_overview.html), under an [Open Government Licence](http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/doc/open-government-licence/version/3/) - except where data contains personally identifiable information, contains information thats sensitive (for example, because it could affect national security), or where publishing the data would infringe the intellectual property rights of someone outside government
- for services that are on GOV.UK, making sure the online user experience is consistent with GOV.UK - for example, by using GOV.UK headers, footers and styles
- publishing details of components or patterns you create or adapt, so others can benefit from them (for example, on a blog or on a GitHub repository)

list.name: NEW Standard - C) Using the right tools and technology

card.name: 14) Choose the right tools and technology
card.desc:
Choose tools and technology that let you build a good service in a cost effective way. Maximise configurability and minimise the cost of changing direction in future.

**Why its important**

Technology decisions are a significant area of investment for the service. The choices you make will have a huge impact on your ability to build, iterate and operate the service in a sustainable way.

**How its assessed**

Looking at your approach to technical architecture, choice of programming languages, development toolchain and other technology choices, the assessors will want to know that youre:

- using appropriate [tools and technologies](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/choosing-technology-an-introduction) to build and operate a good service in a cost effective way - for example, by automating things where possible
- keeping total cost of ownership to a minimum and preserving your ability to make different choices in future - for example, reducing your chances of getting locked into contracts for specific tools and suppliers by [using open standards](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/working-with-open-standards)
- making good decisions about [what to build, what to buy and when to outsource](link to new guidance)
- making sure you have [full control of any data you store](link to new guidance)

The assessors will also want to see that youre making good progress on fixing any organisational issues which make it difficult to maximise uptime. For example, by agreeing a common set of languages, tools, and ways of working for technical staff - either informally, or through something more formal like [the GDS way](https://gds-way.cloudapps.digital/#content).

list.name: NEW Standard - B) Running a service

card.name: 13) Test the service with the minister (or equivalent)
card.desc:
For significant services, get the minister (or an equivalent person) to experience an end to end journey through the service. Including online and offline parts.

**Why its important**

When most people come into contact with government, its through the services government provides. And government spends more money on providing services than anything else.

So its important that the person responsible for representing the interests of the public has first hand experience of using the organisations services. And can judge whether those services are solving problems for users.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will take your word that the minister (or equivalent person) has tested the service.

But its good opportunity for them to talk publicly about the challenges youve overcome and what youve achieved for users. And to get the organisation as a whole enthused about delivering user centred services.

list.name: NEW Standard - B) Running a service

card.name: 12) Define what success looks like and report performance data
card.desc:
Work out what success looks like for your service and identify metrics which will tell you whats working and what can be improved, combined with user research.

You should be collecting and using performance data from all channels, online and offline.

Collect and publish mandatory key performance indicator (KPI) data on the Service Performance platform.

Iterate and improve your metrics and data collection practices as you learn more about user needs. 

**Why its important**

Defining what good looks like and identifying appropriate metrics means that youll know whether the service is solving the problem its meant to solve. 

Collecting the right performance data means youll be alerted to potential problems with your service. And when you make a change to the service, youll be able to tell whether it had the effect you expected.

Publishing performance data means that youre being transparent about the success of services funded by public money. And people can make comparisons between different government services.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to see:

- that youve identified [metrics which will tell you that the service is solving the problem its meant to solve](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/measuring-success/how-to-set-performance-metrics-for-your-service), and that youre tracking performance against them
- that youre using the data to make decisions about how to fix problems and improve the service
- that youre on track to publish data on the [mandatory key performance indicators (KPIs)](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/measuring-success/sharing-your-data-with-the-performance-platform) covering the end to end service

list.name: NEW Standard - B) Running a service

card.name: 11) Encourage people to use the service online
card.desc:
You should have an ambitious plan to encourage people to use your service online when thats the best, most cost effective way of meeting their needs. 

But the plan shouldnt risk excluding people because of digital skills, confidence or access to technology.

**Why its important**

Many users prefer to use services online. And thats usually cheaper for government. So its important to encourage people to use them where appropriate.

But dont aim to deliver all aspects of the service online at any cost. For example, if a user needs complex advice, a telephone call may be a better way to solve their problem. Pushing these users to online channels wont solve their problem effectively, and is likely to be a false economy for government.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know that you have an ambitious but credible [plan to increase digital take up of the service[(https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/helping-people-to-use-your-service/encouraging-people-to-use-your-digital-service).

list.name: NEW Standard - B) Running a service

card.name: 10) Operate a reliable service
card.desc:
Minimise service downtime and have a plan to deal with it when does happen.

**Why its important**

Users expect online services to be available 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. Thats a big part of the reason why many users prefer to use services online.

Many users have limited choice over how and when they access government services. For example, they may be [a carer who only has time to apply for benefits in the early hours of the morning](https://gds.blog.gov.uk/2014/11/28/simpler-carers-allowance-digital-service-now-live/). Downtime can mean those users arent able to get the help they need.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know that:

- youre [monitoring the status of your service](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/monitoring-the-status-of-your-service)
- youre [maximising uptime and availability for the online part of your service](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/uptime-and-availability-keeping-your-service-online) in a way thats proportionate given the impact of downtime on users and government
- youre making good progress on fixing any organisational issues which make it difficult to maximise uptime (for example, by agreeing a common set of languages, tools, and ways of working for technical staff - either informally, or through something more formal like [the GDS way](https://gds-way.cloudapps.digital/#content))
- youre making good progress on fixing any issues with contracts or suppliers which make it difficult to maximise uptime

list.name: NEW Standard - B) Running a service

list.name: NEW Standard - B) Running a service
NEW Standard - A) Meeting users' needs

card.name: 8) Iterate and improve frequently
card.desc:
Make sure you have the capacity, resources and technical flexibility to iterate and improve the service frequently.

**Why its important**

Services are never finished. Using agile methods means getting real people using your service as early as possible, adding refinements and new features as you learn about user needs.

For example, with technology that means more than doing basic maintenance like fixing bugs and deploying patches.

If thats all you do, youll be fixing symptoms rather than underlying problems. And over time, [the service will stop meeting user needs and the technology will accumulate unsustainable technical debt](https://18f.gsa.gov/2016/02/23/software-maintenance-is-an-anti-pattern/).

**How its assessed**

Assessors will want to see an operating plan and budget that allows you to make substantial improvements throughout the lifetime of the service.

People and resources for continuous improvement must be allocated at the level of the [whole service](link-to-whole-service-point) rather than to an individual transaction. That way they can tackle the root cause of problems, wherever they are.

All services will need to do continuous improvement. But the level of intensity will depend on:

- what the service health indicators say
- how critical the service is to users and government
- whether there are external factors the service needs to respond to - for example changes in technology or government policy

Service health indicators could include:

- [performance metrics](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/measuring-success/how-to-set-performance-metrics-for-your-service)
- web analytics (for example, an increase in on-page searches might mean -
 theres a user need thats not being met)
- analysis of support tickets and user feedback
- user research

Dont assume that youll be doing most of the work before the service goes live. With computer software, for example, [its normal to spend more on maintaining the software than you do building it in the first place](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/karchworld_identity/2011/04/01/lehmans-laws-of-software-evolution-and-the-staged-model).

**Further reading**

[The quick and the dead, or 6 things that change when your service goes live](https://blog.mattedgar.com/2016/09/15/the-quick-and-the-dead-or-6-things-that-change-when-your-service-goes-live/)

card.name: 7) Build the service with a multidisciplinary team
card.desc:
Put in place a suitable multidisciplinary team that can build and operate the service in a sustainable way.

**Why its important**

With agile ways of working, the unit of delivery is an empowered, autonomous team. This means youll need people with a diverse mix of skills and expertise.

And its important that these people are part of the team, so theyre accountable to the team and can help the team iterate quickly.

For example, if user research is carried out on the team rather than by someone in a different department, its much more likely to answer the questions the team are asking right now. And the team can use the insight right away to inform the next iteration of the service.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know that:

- you have a [multidisciplinary team](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/the-team) in place thats appropriate to what you need to achieve during this phase of the services development
- the team includes people with expertise in how services are delivered across all the relevant offline channels, and the back end systems the service will have to integrate with
- the team has access to the specialist expertise it needs (for example legal, policy or industry-specific analysis)
- if youre [working with contractors and outside suppliers](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/the-team/working-contractors-third-parties), youre doing it in a sustainable way
- the team is sponsored and supported by a suitably senior service owner

To some extent, the team will be shaped by what youre doing. For example, if youre doing an alpha and youve agreed with the assessors that your riskiest assumptions are to do with design rather than technology, you might need less involvement from a technical architect.

But the assessors will start by assuming that youll need a broad range of roles on the team. A team with diversity of experience is more likely to come up with the best solution.

card.name: 6) Use agile methods
card.desc:
Build the service using agile, iterative, user-centred methods.

**Why its important**

Using agile methods means getting your service in front of real users as quickly as possible. Then observing and generating data on how they use it, and iterating the service based on what youve learned. 

Because youre not specifying everything up front before youve developed an understanding of what users need, agile methods reduce the risk of building the wrong thing. Or building the right thing in the wrong way.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know that:

- the team is using [agile ways of working](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/agile-delivery) - inspecting, learning and adapting as they go
- the team is accountable to the organisations in a way thats consistent with the [agile governance principles](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/agile-delivery/governance-principles-for-agile-service-delivery)

card.name: 5) Make sure everyone can use the service
card.desc:
Provide a service that everyone can use to get the outcome they need. Including people with disabilities, people who dont have access to technology and people who lack the skills or confidence to use it.

**Why its important**

Government services must be accessible to everyone who needs to use them, regardless of disability. And regardless of their access to or ability to use technology.

Its against the law to exclude anyone because of a disability or because of other protected characteristics like race, gender or sexual orientation.

Accessible services are better for everyone. For example, simple language and clear typography is better for someone in a hurry as well as someone with a visual impairment.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know:

- that all parts of the service, online and offline, will meet the required [accessibility standards](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/helping-people-to-use-your-service/making-your-service-accessible-an-introduction)
- that your user research includes participants who are [representative of the potential audience for the service](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/user-research/find-user-research-participants), including people with access needs
- that the service doesnt exclude anyone on the basis race, gender or sexual orientation or other protected characteristics [new-guidance]
that the service is on track to include appropriate support for users who are not able to use the digital service in place by the time it goes into public beta.

card.name: 4) Make the service simple to use
card.desc:
Build a service thats at least as simple, intuitive and comprehensible as the best non-government services by testing it with real users.

**Why its important**

People expect services to just work, and government services should be no exception. Make a service thats as simple to use as possible by testing it with real users.

It costs government time and money to deal with mistakes that are made because of unnecessary complexity. And complexity undermines trust in government.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to see that:

- the service is as least as simple to use as the best non-government services
- youre testing the usability of the service frequently, using appropriate research techniques
- youre testing the end to end service - including offline parts like letters as well as the online parts
- the online part of the service is designed to work on [the widest possible range of devices](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/designing-for-different-browsers-and-devices) 
where possible, youve taken opportunities to reuse or build on [design patterns](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/design#find-patterns) that have been used to solve similar problems
- online parts of the service are consistent with the design of GOV.UK
any text in the service, online or offline, follows the [GOV.UK style guide](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/style-guide)

card.name: 3) Design an end-to-end service
card.desc:
Create a single service that meets users needs across all channels, online and offline.

**Why its important**

If a service doesnt meet a users expectations, they dont experience that as a technology problem, a policy problem or an operational problem: its just a problem.

Bringing different channels together means the service as a whole works better for users. Because people working on the service are empowered to fix problems rather than having to shift them from from one channel to another.

It works better for government, because it means dealing with less failure demand.

And if standards are consistently high across all channels, users are less likely to be disadvantaged or excluded because they lack access to technology or the skills to use it.

**How its assessed**

Assessors will look for evidence that youre being ambitious and making good progress towards creating a single service.

For example:

- theres a single service owner who is empowered to make decisions across all channels, online and offline
- the service team is empowered to find the best way of solving the problem
operations and policy people attend user research and are represented on the service team
- the service team is testing and can make changes to users experience of both online and offline channels (for example, telephony services and letters)
- data from offline channels is used to improve the online part of the service, and the other way around
- you have a plan to remove any technology constraints that make it more difficult than it needs to be to design and operate a single service
- you have a plan to remove any structural, governance or funding problems that make it more difficult than it needs to be to design and operate a single service
- you have a plan to remove any legislative constraints that make it more difficult than it needs to be to design and operate a single service

Further reading

On self-service and support-driven development in government technology

card.name: 2) Solve the whole problem for the user
card.desc:
Create a service that solves one whole problem for users, working across organisational boundaries where necessary.

**Why its important**

Fragmented services are difficult to use, because they make the user do the hard work to make sure theyre doing whats expected of them. For example, working out which of several similar schemes theyre eligible for. Or choosing the right form out of several near-identical options.

This means designing journeys through the various elements of the service - website content and transactions - irrespective of which organisation they belong to. Users shouldnt have to understand how government works in order to use public services.

It doesnt mean aggregating everything together into a single transaction. Overly complex services are just as difficult to use as fragmented services. And theyre harder to fix.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to see that:

- youve [defined the scope of transactions](link to new guidance) so theyre not too narrow or too broad
- youre releasing new functionality as soon as possible - but only in increments that solve a recognisable problem for users, and are easy for them to use
- you have an ambitious but achievable plan to bring existing transactions and content together into a coherent service that solves a whole problem for users (for example, with complex services that cover multiple transactions it might make sense to [start by fixing the content](https://medium.com/@stephen.gill/practical-transformation-start-by-making-things-a-bit-less-rubbish-e89986adbeb1))
- youve got agreement to the plan from organisations who are responsible for the different parts of the user journey (for example, the GDS content team for services that start in GOV.UK mainstream content)
- youre publishing things that will help the rest of government understand what problem youre working on, to increase the potential for collaboration and reduce the potential for duplication (for example business cases, mission statements, user experience maps, maps of existing services and [Wardley maps](http://blog.gardeviance.org/2013/03/basics-repeated-again.html))
- youre working towards sharing data with other government organisations rather than asking users to provide the same information twice (while respecting users privacy and right to control their personal information)
you have arrangements for [working across organisational boundaries](link to new guidance) so you can move towards creating a whole service

card.name: 1) Understand users and their needs
card.desc:
Employ the right user research and data analysis techniques to develop a deep understanding of your users and the problem youre trying to solve for them. Test potential solutions with real, representative users. Make user research and analysis of data the basis for your decision making.

**Why its important**

Developing a deep understanding of users and their needs gives you the best possible chance of meeting their needs in a simple and cost effective way. Its about reducing the risk of building the wrong thing.

Make sure you have a full understanding of the problem youre trying to solve before you commit to a solution. Start with users and their needs rather than with a technical solution. Test your assumptions.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know what youve done to:

- [understand the problem that users need you to solve](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/user-research/start-by-learning-user-needs) 
- make sure youre using the right [combination of interventions](link to new guidance) to solve the problem in the best way - for example building a transaction, publishing website content, running a campaign, partnering with a non-government organisation or making data or an API available

cards.desc:
Build the service using agile, iterative, user-centred methods.

**Why its important**

Using agile methods means getting your service in front of real users as quickly as possible. Then observing and generating data on how they use it, and iterating the service based on what youve learned. 

Because youre not specifying everything up front before youve developed an understanding of what users need, agile methods reduce the risk of building the wrong thing. Or building the right thing in the wrong way.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know that:

- the team is using [agile ways of working](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/agile-delivery) - inspecting, learning and adapting as they go
- the team is accountable to the organisations in a way thats consistent with the [agile governance principles](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/agile-delivery/governance-principles-for-agile-service-delivery)
cards.name: 6) Use agile methods

cards.desc:
Put in place a suitable multidisciplinary team that can build and operate the service in a sustainable way.

**Why its important**

With agile ways of working, the unit of delivery is an empowered, autonomous team. This means youll need people with a diverse mix of skills and expertise.

And its important that these people are part of the team, so theyre accountable to the team and can help the team iterate quickly.

For example, if user research is carried out on the team rather than by someone in a different department, its much more likely to answer the questions the team are asking right now. And the team can use the insight right away to inform the next iteration of the service.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know that:

- you have a [multidisciplinary team](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/the-team) in place thats appropriate to what you need to achieve during this phase of the services development
- the team includes people with expertise in how services are delivered across all the relevant offline channels, and the back end systems the service will have to integrate with
- the team has access to the specialist expertise it needs (for example legal, policy or industry-specific analysis)
- if youre [working with contractors and outside suppliers](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/the-team/working-contractors-third-parties), youre doing it in a sustainable way
- the team is sponsored and supported by a suitably senior service owner

To some extent, the team will be shaped by what youre doing. For example, if youre doing an alpha and youve agreed with the assessors that your riskiest assumptions are to do with design rather than technology, you might need less involvement from a technical architect.

But the assessors will start by assuming that youll need a broad range of roles on the team. A team with diversity of experience is more likely to come up with the best solution.
cards.name: 7) Build the service with a multidisciplinary team

cards.desc:
Make sure you have the capacity, resources and technical flexibility to iterate and improve the service frequently.

**Why its important**

Services are never finished. Using agile methods means getting real people using your service as early as possible, adding refinements and new features as you learn about user needs.

For example, with technology that means more than doing basic maintenance like fixing bugs and deploying patches.

If thats all you do, youll be fixing symptoms rather than underlying problems. And over time, [the service will stop meeting user needs and the technology will accumulate unsustainable technical debt](https://18f.gsa.gov/2016/02/23/software-maintenance-is-an-anti-pattern/).

**How its assessed**

Assessors will want to see an operating plan and budget that allows you to make substantial improvements throughout the lifetime of the service.

People and resources for continuous improvement must be allocated at the level of the [whole service](link-to-whole-service-point) rather than to an individual transaction. That way they can tackle the root cause of problems, wherever they are.

All services will need to do continuous improvement. But the level of intensity will depend on:

- what the service health indicators say
- how critical the service is to users and government
- whether there are external factors the service needs to respond to - for example changes in technology or government policy

Service health indicators could include:

- [performance metrics](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/measuring-success/how-to-set-performance-metrics-for-your-service)
- web analytics (for example, an increase in on-page searches might mean -
 theres a user need thats not being met)
- analysis of support tickets and user feedback
- user research

Dont assume that youll be doing most of the work before the service goes live. With computer software, for example, [its normal to spend more on maintaining the software than you do building it in the first place](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/karchworld_identity/2011/04/01/lehmans-laws-of-software-evolution-and-the-staged-model).

**Further reading**

[The quick and the dead, or 6 things that change when your service goes live](https://blog.mattedgar.com/2016/09/15/the-quick-and-the-dead-or-6-things-that-change-when-your-service-goes-live/)
cards.name: 8) Iterate and improve frequently

cards.desc:
Evaluate what data and information the service will be providing or storing. Address the security level, legal responsibilities, privacy issues and risks associated with the service (consulting experts where appropriate).

**Why its important**

Government services often hold confidential and sensitive information about users. Government has a legal duty to protect this information. And failing to do so would undermine public trust in government services. 

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to see:

- that youve identified security and privacy threats to the service
- that you have a robust, proportionate plan and budget for managing security during the life of the service (for example, responding to threats and applying security patches to software)
- that youve identified fraud vectors and put controls in place
- that youre [collecting users personal information](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1STnlJYyHUGNpMxJuPCGG5J9FZX4PmxkyHxs3poDNtYw/edit) in a way thats secure
- that if the service needs an authentication solution, youve [picked one -
 that balances the risks in a proportionate way](link to new guidance)
- that youre working with business and information risk teams (for example, senior information risk owner (SIRO) information asset owner (IAO) and data guardians) to make sure you meet security regulations without putting delivery at risk
- that youve carried out appropriate [vulnerability and penetration testing](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/vulnerability-and-penetration-testing)
cards.name: 9) Protect users' privacy

cards.desc:
Minimise service downtime and have a plan to deal with it when does happen.

**Why its important**

Users expect online services to be available 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. Thats a big part of the reason why many users prefer to use services online.

Many users have limited choice over how and when they access government services. For example, they may be [a carer who only has time to apply for benefits in the early hours of the morning](https://gds.blog.gov.uk/2014/11/28/simpler-carers-allowance-digital-service-now-live/). Downtime can mean those users arent able to get the help they need.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know that:

- youre [monitoring the status of your service](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/monitoring-the-status-of-your-service)
- youre [maximising uptime and availability for the online part of your service](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/uptime-and-availability-keeping-your-service-online) in a way thats proportionate given the impact of downtime on users and government
- youre making good progress on fixing any organisational issues which make it difficult to maximise uptime (for example, by agreeing a common set of languages, tools, and ways of working for technical staff - either informally, or through something more formal like [the GDS way](https://gds-way.cloudapps.digital/#content))
- youre making good progress on fixing any issues with contracts or suppliers which make it difficult to maximise uptime
cards.name: 10) Operate a reliable service

cards.desc:
You should have an ambitious plan to encourage people to use your service online when thats the best, most cost effective way of meeting their needs. 

But the plan shouldnt risk excluding people because of digital skills, confidence or access to technology.

**Why its important**

Many users prefer to use services online. And thats usually cheaper for government. So its important to encourage people to use them where appropriate.

But dont aim to deliver all aspects of the service online at any cost. For example, if a user needs complex advice, a telephone call may be a better way to solve their problem. Pushing these users to online channels wont solve their problem effectively, and is likely to be a false economy for government.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know that you have an ambitious but credible [plan to increase digital take up of the service[(https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/helping-people-to-use-your-service/encouraging-people-to-use-your-digital-service).
cards.name: 11) Encourage people to use the service online

cards.desc:
Work out what success looks like for your service and identify metrics which will tell you whats working and what can be improved, combined with user research.

You should be collecting and using performance data from all channels, online and offline.

Collect and publish mandatory key performance indicator (KPI) data on the Service Performance platform.

Iterate and improve your metrics and data collection practices as you learn more about user needs. 

**Why its important**

Defining what good looks like and identifying appropriate metrics means that youll know whether the service is solving the problem its meant to solve. 

Collecting the right performance data means youll be alerted to potential problems with your service. And when you make a change to the service, youll be able to tell whether it had the effect you expected.

Publishing performance data means that youre being transparent about the success of services funded by public money. And people can make comparisons between different government services.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to see:

- that youve identified [metrics which will tell you that the service is solving the problem its meant to solve](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/measuring-success/how-to-set-performance-metrics-for-your-service), and that youre tracking performance against them
- that youre using the data to make decisions about how to fix problems and improve the service
- that youre on track to publish data on the [mandatory key performance indicators (KPIs)](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/measuring-success/sharing-your-data-with-the-performance-platform) covering the end to end service
cards.name: 12) Define what success looks like and report performance data

cards.desc: Allow ASRU users to set themselves in-system reminders (that other ASRU users can see). This might be to revoke a PIL on a specific date, or follow up on a time-related PPL condition. NB, this is a reminder, not an automated future action.
cards.name: Set reminders

cards.desc:
For significant services, get the minister (or an equivalent person) to experience an end to end journey through the service. Including online and offline parts.

**Why its important**

When most people come into contact with government, its through the services government provides. And government spends more money on providing services than anything else.

So its important that the person responsible for representing the interests of the public has first hand experience of using the organisations services. And can judge whether those services are solving problems for users.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will take your word that the minister (or equivalent person) has tested the service.

But its good opportunity for them to talk publicly about the challenges youve overcome and what youve achieved for users. And to get the organisation as a whole enthused about delivering user centred services.

cards.name: NTS Categorisation?

cards.desc:
Choose tools and technology that let you build a good service in a cost effective way. Maximise configurability and minimise the cost of changing direction in future.

**Why its important**

Technology decisions are a significant area of investment for the service. The choices you make will have a huge impact on your ability to build, iterate and operate the service in a sustainable way.

**How its assessed**

Looking at your approach to technical architecture, choice of programming languages, development toolchain and other technology choices, the assessors will want to know that youre:

- using appropriate [tools and technologies](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/choosing-technology-an-introduction) to build and operate a good service in a cost effective way - for example, by automating things where possible
- keeping total cost of ownership to a minimum and preserving your ability to make different choices in future - for example, reducing your chances of getting locked into contracts for specific tools and suppliers by [using open standards](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/working-with-open-standards)
- making good decisions about [what to build, what to buy and when to outsource](link to new guidance)
- making sure you have [full control of any data you store](link to new guidance)

The assessors will also want to see that youre making good progress on fixing any organisational issues which make it difficult to maximise uptime. For example, by agreeing a common set of languages, tools, and ways of working for technical staff - either informally, or through something more formal like [the GDS way](https://gds-way.cloudapps.digital/#content).
cards.name: 14) Choose the right tools and technology

cards.desc:
Where possible, build on common standards, components and patterns from inside and outside government. If you develop your own patterns or components, share them publicly so others can use them.

**Why its important**

Using common components and patterns means you dont have to solve problems that have already been solved. By using a component or pattern thats already been extensively tested, you can provide users with a good experience in a cost effective way.

If you develop your own components or patterns, its important to share them so that others can benefit from your work.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to see that youre:

- using and contributing to [open standards](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/working-with-open-standards) where possible
- using [standard government technology components](https://www.gov.uk/government/policies/government-as-a-platform) where possible, for example GOV.UK Verify for identity assurance
- making it as easy as possible to reconfigure your service and for others to build on it, for example by using and creating [application programming interfaces (APIs)](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/choosing-technology-an-introduction) and [registers](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/registers) where possible
- [publishing all data as open data](http://guidance.data.gov.uk/publishing_on_data_gov_uk_overview.html), under an [Open Government Licence](http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/doc/open-government-licence/version/3/) - except where data contains personally identifiable information, contains information thats sensitive (for example, because it could affect national security), or where publishing the data would infringe the intellectual property rights of someone outside government
- for services that are on GOV.UK, making sure the online user experience is consistent with GOV.UK - for example, by using GOV.UK headers, footers and styles
- publishing details of components or patterns you create or adapt, so others can benefit from them (for example, on a blog or on a GitHub repository)
cards.name: 15) Use and contribute to common standards, components and platforms

cards.desc:
Make all new source code open and reusable, and publish it under appropriate licences. Or if this isnt possible, provide a convincing explanation of why this cant be done for specific subsets of the source code.

**Why its important**

Public services are built with public money. So unless theres a good reason not to, the code theyre based should be made available for people outside government to reuse and build on.

Open source code can be reused by developers working in government, avoiding duplication of work and reducing costs for government as a whole. And publishing source code under an open licence means that youre less likely to get locked in to working with a single supplier.  

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want:

- to see that youve written code in the open from the start, and published it in a repository on the internet - minus any sensitive information, like secret keys and credentials
- confirmation that government owns the intellectual property in the code, and that youre publishing it under an open licence

There are a few cases when [you must not publish code in the open](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/open-source-guidance/when-code-should-be-open-or-closed). For example, code that relates to a sensitive government policy that hasnt been announced yet.

**Further reading**

- [Making source code open and reusable](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/making-source-code-open-and-reusable)
- [The benefits of coding in the open](https://gds.blog.gov.uk/2017/09/04/the-benefits-of-coding-in-the-open)
cards.name: 16) Make new source code open
Historical view of licence holders or those with named roles - my establishment

cards.desc:
Test the technology youre working with regularly. 

**Why its important**

Testing is the only way to be confident that your service can cope with the demands likely to be placed on it, and that it works on a wide range of devices.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know that you:

- have an [effective deployment environment](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/making-software/deployment.html)
- can create new environments quickly and easily
- know the data that exists in your pre-production environments
are carrying out [quality assurance testing](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/quality-assurance-testing-your-service-regularly) regularly
- are testing your service in an environment thats as similar to live as possible
- have tested the front end with the [required combination of browsers and devices](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/designing-for-different-browsers-and-devices#test-for-compatibility)
cards.name: 17) Test the technology

cards.name: In-system notifications

cards.desc:
Employ the right user research and data analysis techniques to develop a deep understanding of your users and the problem youre trying to solve for them. Test potential solutions with real, representative users. Make user research and analysis of data the basis for your decision making.

**Why its important**

Developing a deep understanding of users and their needs gives you the best possible chance of meeting their needs in a simple and cost effective way. Its about reducing the risk of building the wrong thing.

Make sure you have a full understanding of the problem youre trying to solve before you commit to a solution. Start with users and their needs rather than with a technical solution. Test your assumptions.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know what youve done to:

- [understand the problem that users need you to solve](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/user-research/start-by-learning-user-needs) 
- make sure youre using the right [combination of interventions](link to new guidance) to solve the problem in the best way - for example building a transaction, publishing website content, running a campaign, partnering with a non-government organisation or making data or an API available
cards.name: 1) Understand users and their needs

cards.desc: Users can add their training when applying for a PIL and a PPL (work to be done). We may want to allow them to add training separately (through their profile), and play back training added in their profile - or we simply only allow users to add training at the point of licence application/amendment.
cards.name: Training in profiles

cards.desc:
Create a service that solves one whole problem for users, working across organisational boundaries where necessary.

**Why its important**

Fragmented services are difficult to use, because they make the user do the hard work to make sure theyre doing whats expected of them. For example, working out which of several similar schemes theyre eligible for. Or choosing the right form out of several near-identical options.

This means designing journeys through the various elements of the service - website content and transactions - irrespective of which organisation they belong to. Users shouldnt have to understand how government works in order to use public services.

It doesnt mean aggregating everything together into a single transaction. Overly complex services are just as difficult to use as fragmented services. And theyre harder to fix.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to see that:

- youve [defined the scope of transactions](link to new guidance) so theyre not too narrow or too broad
- youre releasing new functionality as soon as possible - but only in increments that solve a recognisable problem for users, and are easy for them to use
- you have an ambitious but achievable plan to bring existing transactions and content together into a coherent service that solves a whole problem for users (for example, with complex services that cover multiple transactions it might make sense to [start by fixing the content](https://medium.com/@stephen.gill/practical-transformation-start-by-making-things-a-bit-less-rubbish-e89986adbeb1))
- youve got agreement to the plan from organisations who are responsible for the different parts of the user journey (for example, the GDS content team for services that start in GOV.UK mainstream content)
- youre publishing things that will help the rest of government understand what problem youre working on, to increase the potential for collaboration and reduce the potential for duplication (for example business cases, mission statements, user experience maps, maps of existing services and [Wardley maps](http://blog.gardeviance.org/2013/03/basics-repeated-again.html))
- youre working towards sharing data with other government organisations rather than asking users to provide the same information twice (while respecting users privacy and right to control their personal information)
you have arrangements for [working across organisational boundaries](link to new guidance) so you can move towards creating a whole service
cards.name: 2) Solve the whole problem for the user

cards.desc:
Create a single service that meets users needs across all channels, online and offline.

**Why its important**

If a service doesnt meet a users expectations, they dont experience that as a technology problem, a policy problem or an operational problem: its just a problem.

Bringing different channels together means the service as a whole works better for users. Because people working on the service are empowered to fix problems rather than having to shift them from from one channel to another.

It works better for government, because it means dealing with less failure demand.

And if standards are consistently high across all channels, users are less likely to be disadvantaged or excluded because they lack access to technology or the skills to use it.

**How its assessed**

Assessors will look for evidence that youre being ambitious and making good progress towards creating a single service.

For example:

- theres a single service owner who is empowered to make decisions across all channels, online and offline
- the service team is empowered to find the best way of solving the problem
operations and policy people attend user research and are represented on the service team
- the service team is testing and can make changes to users experience of both online and offline channels (for example, telephony services and letters)
- data from offline channels is used to improve the online part of the service, and the other way around
- you have a plan to remove any technology constraints that make it more difficult than it needs to be to design and operate a single service
- you have a plan to remove any structural, governance or funding problems that make it more difficult than it needs to be to design and operate a single service
- you have a plan to remove any legislative constraints that make it more difficult than it needs to be to design and operate a single service

Further reading

On self-service and support-driven development in government technology
cards.name: 3) Design an end-to-end service

cards.desc:
Build a service thats at least as simple, intuitive and comprehensible as the best non-government services by testing it with real users.

**Why its important**

People expect services to just work, and government services should be no exception. Make a service thats as simple to use as possible by testing it with real users.

It costs government time and money to deal with mistakes that are made because of unnecessary complexity. And complexity undermines trust in government.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to see that:

- the service is as least as simple to use as the best non-government services
- youre testing the usability of the service frequently, using appropriate research techniques
- youre testing the end to end service - including offline parts like letters as well as the online parts
- the online part of the service is designed to work on [the widest possible range of devices](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/technology/designing-for-different-browsers-and-devices) 
where possible, youve taken opportunities to reuse or build on [design patterns](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/design#find-patterns) that have been used to solve similar problems
- online parts of the service are consistent with the design of GOV.UK
any text in the service, online or offline, follows the [GOV.UK style guide](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/style-guide)
cards.name: 4) Make the service simple to use

cards.desc:
Provide a service that everyone can use to get the outcome they need. Including people with disabilities, people who dont have access to technology and people who lack the skills or confidence to use it.

**Why its important**

Government services must be accessible to everyone who needs to use them, regardless of disability. And regardless of their access to or ability to use technology.

Its against the law to exclude anyone because of a disability or because of other protected characteristics like race, gender or sexual orientation.

Accessible services are better for everyone. For example, simple language and clear typography is better for someone in a hurry as well as someone with a visual impairment.

**How its assessed**

The assessors will want to know:

- that all parts of the service, online and offline, will meet the required [accessibility standards](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/helping-people-to-use-your-service/making-your-service-accessible-an-introduction)
- that your user research includes participants who are [representative of the potential audience for the service](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/user-research/find-user-research-participants), including people with access needs
- that the service doesnt exclude anyone on the basis race, gender or sexual orientation or other protected characteristics [new-guidance]
that the service is on track to include appropriate support for users who are not able to use the digital service in place by the time it goes into public beta.
cards.name: 5) Make sure everyone can use the service
